tweets.text:
Ironbridge temporary flood barriers going up tomorrow. 

Due to heavy rain across Shropshire & upper Severn, barriers are needed to protect communities from #flooding. 

Wharfage resurfacing prep work had started, however this work is postponed while the barriers are needed. https://t.co/sY7ue1o4Lf

Monksleaze was closed early this morning, the Sowy has returned to its normal winter level. We will be allowing the KSD level to fall substantially overnight to allow for some new flow monitoring equipment to be installed before the next band of rain comes in. #KSD  @EnvAgencySW

Over the coming days heavy rain is forecast for Yorkshire and the North East as #StormChristoph hits the region.  To sign up for flood alerts please visit the @EnvAgency website https://t.co/08qhBLjngI people can also call our Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60 #PrepareActSurvive https://t.co/z5e85DblaG

‚ùó A flood warning has now been issued by the @EnvAgency for Ford Lane/Cheadle Wood following heavy rain (please see map below).
River levels are rising as a result of heavy rainfall associated with Storm Christoph. Flooding to properties in this area is expected
#stormchristoph https://t.co/6SzSGVe0uv

‚òî Heavy rain will continue across #WestYorkshire today. If you live in a #flood area and are worried about your property #flooding, consider what actions to take now!

#StormChristoph https://t.co/wzIYGZzpiF

#PrepareActSurvive https://t.co/ohmPMGkd1L

Our #partnership teams are out monitoring and are prepared to respond

Thank you to all our flood wardens!

tweets.text: @AndreasHeinem @RobStoneman @EnvAgency @YWDirectors @WildlifeTrusts OK, agreed. So my understanding of the context was that you were using the data from your extensively studied field sites to model the impacts on the entirety of the Ouse catchment? Pretty big context and therefore very important socioeconomic  finding if your work is correct.
@PaulReevesEA @EnvAgencyMids Yup very high here! I actually have no idea how to turn the water off to my house, or isolate our oil tank ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è #littonmill https://t.co/oCHeo24aGT

@TimThom6 @RobStoneman @EnvAgency @YWDirectors @WildlifeTrusts It is all dependent on the context! What is compared & under what conditions! Too often it is misinterpreted and misused. Every word counts. Most important is we need to explore thus indication (!) further - only then will we know more.

For the latest warnings visit ‚û°Ô∏è https://t.co/uGQ4g6A5Xn 

#StormChristoph #Lancashire #GreaterManchester #Cheshire #Merseyside

We know it will happen, yet we still manage the hills to give them the water absorption capacity of tarmac. Stop burning & stop over-grazing to ensure our hills can absorb these storms. Sandbags are not the answer. @EnvAgency @YWDirectors @WildlifeTrusts https://t.co/d5JSR8Ja5N

tweets.text: @AndreasHeinem @RobStoneman @EnvAgency @YWDirectors @WildlifeTrusts Gosh its hard to keep up with the science! "Upscaled flow volumes indicated potentially significant reductions in downstream peak river flooding, estimated to be up to 50cm under mowing compared to burning" Heinemeyer et al 2018. Suggests a possible link?

tweets.text: @RobStoneman @EnvAgency @YWDirectors @WildlifeTrusts We don't actually have robust evidence to link burning to flooding - most is on eroding/bare peat. Moreover, we also don't know yet what rewetted, completely saturated peatlands do under such conditions (where will water go)? Very important questions to really find answers to.

Still hosing it down in Wales.

Our rain gauge near Llyn Clywedog at the headwaters of the Severn has recorded over 120mm since Monday.

More flood warnings inevitable on the Severn & Wye and probably other rivers.

Stay up to date here https://t.co/lay6cxAT3K https://t.co/EQaNGl2lum
